body:
Thanks for the list!

What would be extremely useful is a quick analysis which of these reconciliation strategies can be mapped on transformers (e.g., apply after forecasting, use only forecasts to fit and reconcile), and which need to be wrappers/compositors (e.g., needs the original or historical data, needs to call methods of the forecaster as part of the algorithm).

Good shout Franz - started working on the bottom-up and OLS if you want to have a [look](https://github.com/ciaran-g/sktime/blob/reconciler-bottom-up/examples/hierarchical_play.ipynb)

Transformers:
 - bottom up
 - OLS
 - Weighted LS (structural)

Wrappers/compositors:
- Weighted LS (variance) - uses residuals
- MinT (sample) - uses residuals
- MinT (shrinkage) - uses residuals
- Top down - historic proportions

issue.title: [ENH] Implement reconcilers for hierarchical predictions - transformers

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
-->

This PR adds a reconciler transformer, which takes hierarchical predictions and processes them so they sum appropriately. Three methods are implemented here out of the list in issue #2157
 - bottom up 
 - ols
 - wls_var


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->

Hierarchical reconciler which depends only on the structure of the hierarchy. The three methods are detailed [here](https://otexts.com/fpp3/hierarchical.html) and the code is constructed similar to the methodology as noted in these [slides](https://github.com/robjhyndman/reconciliation_review_talk/blob/main/10years_reconciliation.pdf). The only difference between the three methods is the construction of the "G" matrix.

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

No

<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->

issue.title: [ENH] Aggregator as a transformer

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
-->

This PR adds a aggregator transformer, which takes observations at the bottom level of the hierarchy and sums them according to the index provided. This is linked to PR #2287 and issue #2157


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->

A transformer that takes hierarchical observations at the bottom level of the hierarchy only, and sums them appropriately using the index. An identifier is placed in the index for aggregated nodes called `__total`. The reconciler implemented in #2287 use this identifier, so probably this is a better one to focus on first.

Also I noticed for some reason, if you pass an a non-multiindex type input to the transformer it doesn't raise an error like a guess it should given the tags filled in at the top of the script? I tried to include a test for this as well, but it only seems to work correctly when you call the hidden _transform function 

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->

No

issue.title: [ENH] Top-down reconciler based on forecast proportions

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
See #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->

Added the top down method based on forecast proportions to the Reconcilers. See #2157 

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->

- The new g matrix function for top down - `_get_g_matrix_td_fcst()`
- An update function for the g matrix for this method, which changes for each forecast - `_update_td_fcst()`
- A function for returning a parent/child look up table for all methods - `_parent_child_df()`
- Re-format of the `_transform()` function to incorporate the new method, also uses column/index matching with `df.dot()` now
- Improvements to documentation



#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->

No

issue.title: [ENH] An ensemble type forecaster for panel/hierarchical data

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
For forecasting in a hierarchy it would be nice to be able to use different forecasters for each individual node

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A class similar to `ColumnEnsembleForecaster` but instead of applying a different univariate forecaster per-column, it applies a different univariate forecaster per-level on panel-type data

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
One option is to run a loop or something but it would be difficult to adapt this into #2157

issue.title: [ENH] A new `ReconcilerForecaster` estimator for reconciling forecasts using base model residuals

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->

Added a new estimator `ReconcilerForecaster` which contains three reconciliation methods. See https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2157


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->

A new `ReconcilerForecaster` class which is a composite of a base forecaster and a reconciliation method. The idea/methods are similar to the `Reconciler`, except here the reconciliation matrix is estimated using variations on the base-forecast residual covariance matrix. The three methods either use the sample covariance matrix `method="mint_cov"`, a shrunk covariance matrix `method="mint_shrink"`, or only the on-diagonal elements `method="wls_var"`.

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->

No

#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
-->

I was wondering if it would be easier or more intuitive for users if all of the reconciliation methods, including the transformers, were accessible though this estimator?

##### For all contributions
- [x] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [x] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.
- [x] The PR title starts with either [ENH], [MNT], [DOC], or [BUG] indicating whether the PR topic is related to enhancement, maintenance, documentation, or bug.

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.

<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->
